TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: izua ła maḍusa marekaka.
izoa lja madrosa marekaka.
qau vaik a tjavulung a sema tjatjan.
qao vaik a tjavolong a sema tjatjan.
S.TRANSL: The older one went to the spring,

S.FORM: qau adjuqen i umaq a tjałałak a uqałay.
qao adjoqen i omaq a tjaljaljak a oqaljay.
S.TRANSL: and left the younger brother at home.

S.FORM: qau mangtjez a tjavulung kasi tjatjan.
qao mangtjez a tjavolong kasi tjatjan.
S.TRANSL: When the older one came back from the spring,

S.FORM: neka kaka; inalap na qała, maulaw.
neka kaka; inalap na qalja, maolaw.
S.TRANSL: the brother wasn’t there; he had been taken by enemies and was gone.

S.FORM: qau qemaung a tjavulung: "paramur a semainu a kaka?"
qao qemaong a tjavolong: "paramor a semaino a kaka?"
S.TRANSL: The older one cried: “This is awful(?). Where has brother gone?”

S.FORM: vaik a kemim sa qauqaung.
vaik a kemim sa qaoqaong.
S.TRANSL: She cried and went to look for him.

S.FORM: qau tevuta a tjatjiw kidjekets ta kasiw.
qao tevota a tjatjiw kidjekec ta kasiw.
S.TRANSL: Then a black drongo bird appeared and alighted on a tree.

S.FORM: qau "tjatjiw tjatjiw, pagaługału a qemaung.
qao "tjatjiw tjatjiw, pagaljogaljo a qemaong.
pazeliułi aken ta kałaułavan.
pazeliolji aken ta kaljaoljavan.
ku sikiliłkauław a su pałekakain i tjuruzaquzaquin."
ko sikililjkaoljaw a so paljekakain i tjorozaqozaqoin."
S.TRANSL: and I’ll bring back (?) your brother from the sapindus wood.”

S.FORM: qau pavayin ta qalev.
qao pavayin ta qalev.
S.TRANSL: She gave the bird some oil.

S.FORM: qau ka maka qalev, qau senay: "tjatjiw tjatjiw, imazamaza-u.
qao ka maka qalev, qao senay: "tjatjiw tjatjiw, imazamaza-o.
S.TRANSL: When it had finished oiling itself, it sang: “Tjatjiw tjatjiw, stay here.

S.FORM: ku sikiliłkauław a su pałekakain i tjuruzaquzaquin."
ko sikililjkaoljaw a so paljekakain i tjorozaqozaqoin."
S.TRANSL: I’ll bring back your brother from the sapindus wood.”

S.FORM: qau vaik a malap ta kaka aza tjatjiw.
qao vaik a malap ta kaka aza tjatjiw.
S.TRANSL: So the bird went to get the brother.

S.FORM: tevuta a kaka kinatsukatsu na tjatjiw.
tevota a kaka kinacokaco na tjatjiw.
S.TRANSL: The brother appeared, carried by the bird.

S.FORM: qau avan a nu sikełang ta tjatjiw tu mamazangiłan.
qao avan a no sikeljang ta tjatjiw to mamazangiljan.
S.TRANSL: And that’s how we know that the black drongo bird is of chiefly rank.

S.FORM: qau inika qetsiqetsiin na Payuan a tjatjiw.
qao inika qeciqeciin na Payoan a tjatjiw.
S.TRANSL: And Paiwan people don’t kill a black drongo bird.
